choices.text: 1 → A, 2 → D, 3 → C, 4 → E, 5 → B
1 → F, 2 → D, 3 → G, 4 → A, 5 → E
1 → A, 2 → D, 3 → B, 4 → E, 5 → G
1 → C, 2 → A, 3 → D, 4 → G, 5 → B

questions.text:
Match the cranial nerve injury in Column A with the most characteristic clinical presentation in Column B:
Choose the correct match:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

By knowing the key signs each cranial nerve injury produces and distinguishing ipsilateral (IL) and contralateral (CL) effects, you can correctly match each nerve with its clinical presentation.

  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) injury causes tongue to deviate toward the affected (IL) side due to unopposed genioglossus of the healthy side.
  • Facial nerve (CN VII - LMN) , lower motor neuron lesion causes complete IL facial paralysis, including forehead.
  • Trigeminal nerve (CN V motor) lesion causes jaw deviation to IL side due to weak pterygoid muscles, and loss of corneal reflex (afferent limb).
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) affects gag reflex (afferent limb) and taste in posterior 1/3 of tongue.
  • Vagus nerve (CN X) causes uvula to deviate to CL side due to palatal muscle weakness.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The large, dome-shaped papillae arranged in a V-shaped row anterior to the sulcus terminalis are circumvallate papillae.

  • The dorsal surface of the tongue has four types of papillae:
    • Filiform papillae : most numerous, slender, conical, and keratinized; they provide a rough texture but lack taste buds. (Option C ruled out)
    • Fungiform papillae : mushroom-shaped, found scattered among filiform papillae, especially at the tip and lateral margins; they contain taste buds. (Option A ruled out)
    • Circumvallate papillae : large, circular, and arranged in a V-shaped row just anterior to the sulcus terminalis; each is surrounded by a trench and has numerous taste buds on its sides. These are associated with von Ebner's glands, which secrete a watery fluid to cleanse the trench.
    • Foliate papillae : leaf-like folds found on the posterolateral edges of the tongue; more prominent in infants, they also contain taste buds. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralyzed when bedridden stroke patient who is right sided hemiplegic is asked to protrude the tongue ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a stroke causing right-sided hemiplegia (left hypoglossal nerve palsy), the left genioglossus is paralyzed, so the tongue deviates toward the left (affected side) when protruded.

The genioglossus is an extrinsic muscle of the tongue. It is a large, thick muscle, which contributes significantly to the shape of the tongue.

  • Attachments: Arises from the mandibular symphysis. It inserts onto the body of the hyoid bone and the entire length of the tongue.
  • Function: Protrusion ('sticking the tongue out') and depression of the tongue. When both the right and left genioglossus contract they protrude the anterior part of the tongue out of the mouth in the midline.
  • Innervation: Hypoglossal nerve.
  • Blood supply: Lingual artery with contributions from the tonsillar artery.

The hyoglossus is an extrinsic muscle of the tongue. It is a thin quadrangular muscle lateral to the genioglossus

  • Attachments: Originate from the superior border of the greater horn and adjacent body of the hyoid bone. Inserts into the side of the tongue, deep to the mylohyoid and styloglossus.
  • Function: Depresses the tongue (pulls it inferiorly) , retracts the tongue (pulls it posteriorly) and assists in flattening the tongue.
  • Innervation: Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
  • Blood Supply: Lingual artery, a branch of the external carotid artery.

Key Takeaway:

Tongue deviation is toward the weak side, which identifies the paralyzed genioglossus.

questions.text: A patient presents with loss of taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and right side facial paralysis. The patient is unable to convey his emotions. General sensation is intact. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Loss of taste in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue with facial weakness but intact general sensation points to injury of the chorda tympani nerve, which carries taste fibers and is a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).

  • The chorda tympani nerve arises from the facial nerve a few millimeters above the stylomastoid foramen.
  • It is directed superior and anterior, and perforates the tympanic cavity. It enters the posterior canaliculus and then descends near the spine of the sphenoid bone.
  • It merges with the lingual nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve (V2) in the infratemporal fossa to reach the tongue.
  • It carries special sensory fibers (taste) from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Also carries parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands via the submandibular ganglion.
  • Injury to the chorda tympani:
    • Causes loss of taste in anterior 2/3rd of tongue.
    • Preserves general sensation, since that is carried by the lingual nerve
    • If the lesion also affects the facial nerve proximal to this, the patient will also show facial weakness and inability to express emotions.

Explanation of other options:

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option B) : Supplies taste and general sensation to the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue , not the anterior 2/3rd.

Hypoglossal nerve (Option C) : Pure motor nerve to tongue muscles , no taste or facial expression involvement.

Lingual nerve (Option D) : Supplies general sensation to anterior 2/3rd of tongue, but not taste; taste fibers come via chorda tympani.

questions.text: A patient with gustatory dysfunction is examined by using taste strips (They are paper strips which are impregnated with one of the four flavors "sweet", "sour", "salty" or "bitter" in four different concentrations) on the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is tested here ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), so applying taste strips to this region specifically tests its function.

Areas innervated by Glossopharyngeal nerve are :

  • Circumvallate papillae
  • Posterior 1/3rd of tongue
  • Palatoglossus arches
  • The oropharynx

The tongue's innervation is divided as follows:

  • Anterior 2/3rd (oral part):
    • Taste: Chorda tympani (branch of facial nerve, CN VII)
    • General sensation: Lingual nerve (branch of mandibular nerve, CN V3)
  • Posterior 1/3rd (pharyngeal part):
    • Taste and general sensation: Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
  • Base of tongue & epiglottis:
    • Taste and general sensation: Vagus nerve (mainly via internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of CN X)

The taste sensation from taste buds in the oral surface of the soft palate is carried by the lesser palatine nerve.

  • The lesser palatine nerves pass through the lesser palatine foramen to innervate the soft palate with contributions from the branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).
  • The lesser palatine nerves also carry taste fibers from the greater petrosal branch of the facial nerve (CN VII) to the taste buds of the soft palate.

choices.text: Taste buds on the posterior third of the tongue

questions.solution:
Explanation:

The facial nerve (CN VII) innervates the muscles of facial expression, including the muscles of the lower lip, through its marginal mandibular branch.

  • The facial nerve (CN VII) has both motor and sensory functions and divides into five terminal motor branches within the parotid gland:
    • Temporal:
      • Frontal belly of occipitofrontalis, orbicularis oculi (upper part), auricular muscles
    • Zygomatic:
      • Lower part of orbicularis oculi, zygomaticus major and minor
    • Buccal:
      • Buccinator, orbicularis oris (upper lip), levator labii superioris, levator anguli oris
    • Marginal mandibular:
      • Muscles of lower lip: depressor anguli oris, depressor labii inferioris, mentalis
    • Cervical:
      • Platysma
  • Other branches before it enters the parotid gland:
    • Nerve to stapedius
      • Stapedius muscle (middle ear) - motor
    • Posterior auricular nerve
      • Occipital belly of occipitofrontalis, auricular muscles
    • Chorda tympani :
      • Special sensory (taste) from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue - motor
Facial Nerve Branches

Explanation of other options:

Taste buds on the posterior third of the tongue (Option A) : Supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not the facial nerve.

Muscles of the soft palate (Option B) : Primarily supplied by the vagus nerve (CN X) and partially by mandibular nerve (CN V3) (for tensor veli palatini), not CN VII.

The parotid salivary gland (Option D) : Though the facial nerve passes through the parotid gland, it does not innervate it. Parasympathetic supply comes from the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) via the otic ganglion.

questions.text: A 25 year old patient presents with Reddish white painful lesion over Marginal part of anterior 2/3rd of tongue. On scraping over lesion bleeding is noticed. Samples taken from lesions are sent for biopsy shows Erythroplakia. Which lymph node biopsy should be examined first ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral part of the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue drains unilaterally into the submandibular lymph nodes, making them the first nodes to be examined in lesions like erythroplakia.

The lymphatic drainage of the tongue is region-specific and clinically important in evaluating premalignant or malignant lesions, especially in conditions like erythroplakia, which has a high risk of transformation to squamous cell carcinoma.

  • Lymphatics of tongue
    • Tip(apex) of tongue : Bilateral submental lymph nodes (Option A ruled out)
    • Marginal part of anterior 2/3rd of tongue : Unilateral submandibular nodes
    • Central part of anterior 2/3rd of tongue : Bilateral jugulodigastric and jugulo-omohyoid lymph nodes (Option D ruled out)
    • Posterior 1/3rd of tongue : Bilateral jugulodigastric and jugulo-omohyoid lymph nodes (Option C ruled out)
    • Root of tongue - Bilateral upper deep cervical

questions.text: First to fifth Occipital somite forms all muscles of the tongue except the muscle derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch. Name the muscle ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All tongue muscles are derived from occipital somites and supplied by the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) except palatoglossus, which arises from the 4th pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the vagus nerve (CN X).

  • Embryological Origin of Tongue Muscles:
    • The muscles of the tongue (except one) develop from the first to fourth occipital somites, which migrate anteriorly into the floor of the mouth. (Options B , C , D ruled out)
    • These muscles are innervated by the nerve of those somites: the hypoglossal nerve (CN XII).
  • Exception : Palatoglossus:
    • Derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch.
    • Innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X) via the pharyngeal plexus.Acts to elevate the posterior part of the tongue and narrow the oropharyngeal isthmus during swallowing.

choices.text: A) Genioglossus B) Hyoglossus c) Styloglossus
A) Styloglossus B) Genioglossus C) Geniohyoid
A) Hyoglossus B) Genioglossus C) Styloglossus
A) Geniohyoid B) Styloglossus C) Hyoglossus

questions.text: Identify the muscles marked.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked muscles are Hyoglossus , Genioglossus and Styloglossus respectively

questions.text: Identify the marked muscle.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked muscle is Hyoglossus.
